comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Photo caption from AWM: "Looking towards Hamel along the communication trench (CT) running from the village to Pear Trench, over the fiercely contested ground won from the enemy in the Australian attack of 4 July 1918. The bodies of two dead German machine gunners bayoneted during the fighting lie on the ground, while the village is being shelled by the enemy. The Germans were caught behind the barrage in the CT and in almost every bay a dead body was found."

comment.author: 82596826@N03
comment._content:
The official caption reads like one of those classic products of a potentially overly imaginative caption writer. The unfortunate soldier in the foreground of the photo above was definitely not officially a "machine gunner"  - nor would it seem so plausible he was "bayoneted".  It's quite possible he was cut down by a shell splinter, or bullet(s) as he was running to help the wounded and now deceased soldier laying in the trench. The attack here was at night after all, so the facts behind this scene are surely uncertain. The accompanying photo in the AWM archives at least proves one thing - he was a wearing a red cross brassard on his arm and the backpack on the ground nearby was probably his bulk first aid kit - ie his normal job was as a Sanitäter (medic):

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/82596826@N03/7746098210/in/photostream]

Both photos were taken on the 5th of July 1918  just to the south of Le Hamel, in Picardie France (ie just south of the Somme River) - ie well over 24 hours after these unfortunate men were killed in action.
